results.title: Kerala
results.creator_credit: T.A. Abraham, Ezra Mir and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A picture of Kerala State in south-west India. A flat fertile land with many waterways supporting a dense population; many crops including spices, for which the district was known to the Arabs and Phoenicians; Vasco da Gama and the history of Kerala; the Byzantine influence in the city of Trivandrum; paintings and sculptures in the museum and much more including the life and customs of the people.
results.creator_credit_for_label: T.A. Abraham, Ezra Mir and Documentary Films of India

results.title: Kepler and his work
results.creator_credit: Education Foundation for Visual Arts and Institut für Film und Bild
results.brief_description: Kepler’s life story, his discovery of the three Laws of Planetary Motion and work of optics. Contemporary prints illustrate his early life and education at the University of Tubingen; concepts of planetary motion held at the time, and the way Kepler’s work altered them; work in Prague leading to the Laws of Planetary Motion; study of optics, astronomical calculations and other publications; his last years, overshadowed by the Thirty Year’s War.

results.title: Kariba game rescue
results.brief_description: The rising waters of the Kariba Dam, largest man made lake in the world, threatened the wildlife in the area until Northern Rhodesian rescue teams put Operation Noah into practice. A typical day’s work is the capture of boatloads of game, such as antelope and zebra and their safe release on dry land.

results.title: Jungle road
results.brief_description: Papua and New guinea today, showing the terrain, people and customs; technical training of the natives; development of agricultural schemes and health services carried out by the New Guinea administration; role of the Twenty-First Construction Squadron of Royal Australian Engineers building new roads, providing electric power and telephone services, constructing houses, a jetty and an airstrip. A new road being built through the rugged Torricelli Mountain range from Wewak to Maprik.

results.title: Judging people
results.creator_credit: Arthur Swerdloff, Leon S. Gold and Roundtable Productions
results.brief_description: Shows frequent pitfalls in sizing up people, as well as methods of avoiding mistakes in making decisions about people, and predicting their performance. Tells how to improve one’s ability to analyze and judge personality, intelligence, ability and capacity.

results.title: Journey into spring
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Edgar H. Anstey, Ian Ferguson and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: Spring comes to Selborne, where the 18th century naturalist Gilbert White made his record of the wild life in his Hampshire parish; rook and dabchick; frog and slow-worm, hedgehog, mole and vole; pussywillow, catkin, celandine, primrose. Two centuries later, as these and other forms of life respond to the seasonal rhythm, the story of spring is patiently recorded by probing camera and microphone and by the evocative words of Laurie Lee.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ralph Keene, Edgar H. Anstey, Ian Ferguson and British Transport Films

results.title: Jordan Paul : one teacher's approach (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Vaughn Ohern, Gary Schlosser and Extension Media Centre
results.brief_description: Jordan Paul’s approach to the drug problem is to relate to his students, by any means he can, in order to communicate about drug abuse. His approach is non-directive, he has problems to over come as an authority figure, but he promotes the substitution of people as an alternative to drugs. High school students discuss aspects of drug education.
